bestBHT.bht: Around noon, darkness covered the earth, obscuring the sun and casting a shadow over all creation. It lasted for three hours, until about three in the afternoon.

John Gill: And it was about the sixth hour,.... Or twelve o'clock at noon; and so the Ethiopic version, when it was noon;
John Wesley: There was darkness over all the earth."
The noon-tide darkness, covering the sun, obscured all the upper hemisphere.
And the lower was equally darkened, the moon being in opposition to the sun, and so receiving no light from it.

bhtAttempts.bht: At about noon, darkness covered the earth, obscuring the sun, while the moon, in opposition to the sun, remained equally dark. This darkness lasted for three hours until about three in the afternoon.
From about noon, darkness enveloped the entire earth, blocking the sunlight and casting a shadow over the land. This darkness persisted for three hours until around three in the afternoon.
Around noon, darkness covered the earth, obscuring the sun and casting a shadow over all creation. It lasted for three hours, until about three in the afternoon.

Around noon, darkness covered the earth, obscuring the sun and casting a shadow over all creation. It lasted for three hours, until about three in the afternoon. This period of darkness was a remarkable occurrence during this time.

At about midday, darkness covered the entire earth, obscuring the sun and creating a profound darkness in both the upper and lower hemispheres. This darkness lasted for three hours, until the ninth hour. The significance of this darkness is unknown, but it undoubtedly added a supernatural element to the events unfolding at that time.
